author: By Mohana Ravindranath
title: Why Do Women Live Longer Than Men?
description: By understanding the reasons, scientists hope to help both sexes age better.
content: Women outlive men, by something of a long shot: In the United States, women have a life expectancy of about 80, compared to around 75 for men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Sweeney
title: Can You Get Rid of Cold Sores for Good?
description: Experts explain what they do, and don’t, recommend.
content: Q: I get cold sores several times a year. Is there a way to keep them from coming back?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fintan O'Toole
title: How Will the West Look Back on the Crisis in Gaza?
description: Omar El Akkad considers American and European responses to mass suffering in his new book.
content: In his dystopian debut novel, “American War” (2017), Omar El Akkad describes a massacre at a refugee camp with calmly horrifying precision. “The bodies made damp pools in the dusty ground,” he observes, through the eyes of a woman called Sarat. “There was a heat to them. Sarat felt it against her skin, damp and real as steam from a boiling pot. She knew what it was. It was the heat of life extinguished. The heat of something leaving.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Ukraine Agreed to Turn Over Mineral Revenue to the U.S.
description: Also, Republicans eyed Medicaid cuts. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Ukraine has agreed to give the U.S. a portion of the revenue from its mineral resources, officials said. The agreement came under heavy pressure from the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Lavish Park Avenue Restaurant Is Out to Seduce You
description: At Four Twenty Five, two top-tier chefs, Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Jonathan Benno, dazzle with a surprising and sumptuous menu.
content: The announcement that the chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten was opening a restaurant in a glassy skyscraper on Park Avenue didn’t surprise me. A madly prolific international restaurateur, he seems to open restaurants like browser tabs (56 to date). My ears perked up when I heard that the new place, Four Twenty Five, was to be a haute cuisine restaurant, Mr. Vongerichten’s first in New York City since 1997, when he debuted the dizzyingly innovative, four-star Jean-Georges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Justice Dept. Takes Broad View of Trump’s Jan. 6 Pardons
description: The department has increasingly taken the position that criminal behavior discovered during an investigation stemming from a suspect’s role in the Capitol attack is in fact related to Jan. 6.
content: Four years ago, when F.B.I. agents searched the Florida home of Jeremy Brown, a former Special Forces soldier, in connection with his role in the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, they found several illegal items: an unregistered assault rifle, two live fragmentation grenades and a classified “trip report” that Mr. Brown wrote while he was in the Army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Hundreds in Park Service Have Opted to Quit, Agency Memo Says
description: The report has raised concerns about national park access and maintenance heading into the summer travel season.
content: More than 700 National Park Service employees have submitted resignations as part of Elon Musk’s “fork in the road” offer, according to an internal agency memo that critics of the plan said would diminish staffing ahead of the busy summer tourism season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: To Identify Suspect in Idaho Killings, F.B.I. Used Restricted Consumer DNA Data
description: New records show that the F.B.I. identified Bryan Kohberger as a potential murder suspect after tapping consumer databases that were supposed to be off limits.
content: As investigators struggled for weeks to find who might have committed the brutal stabbings of four University of Idaho students in the fall of 2022, they were focused on a key piece of evidence: DNA on a knife sheath that was found at the scene of the crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar
title: Should Parents Be Talking to Their Children About Online Pornography?
description: More adolescents than ever are watching it. Is it time for a frank conversation?
content: Teachers: The related article, and the excerpt below, discuss sexual activity and pornography, using graphic language. Please preview these materials before sharing them with students to make sure they are appropriate for your class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: The Disturbing Question at the Heart of the Trump-Putin Drama
description: For the next four years, at least, the America we knew is over.
content: The drama going on between President Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine raises one of the most disturbing questions I’ve ever had to ask about my own country: Are we being led by a dupe for Vladimir Putin — by someone ready to swallow whole the Russian president’s warped view of who started the war in Ukraine and how it must end? Or are we being led by a Mafia godfather, looking to carve up territory with Russia the way the heads of crime families operate? “I’ll take Greenland, and you can take Crimea. I’ll take Panama, and you can have the oil in the Arctic. And we’ll split the rare earths of Ukraine. It’s only fair.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Wednesday Briefing: Taiwan Considers a Changed U.S.
description: Plus, the microphone turns 100.
content: Taiwan could be forced to consider its political future as President Trump turns against Ukraine and abandons Western efforts to punish Russia. Ukraine and Taiwan share a kinship: small democracies laid claim to by hulking, authoritarian neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Want to Talk About Loss? For This Label Head’s Album, Many Stars Did.
description: Richard Russell of XL Recordings’ new album as Everything Is Recorded bridges life and death, with contributions from Florence Welch, Sampha, Noah Cyrus and more.
content: At the height of the pandemic in 2020 and 2021, the English music producer Richard Russell realized how many conversations he was having about mortality and loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Kitamura
title: Solving a Head-Spinning Murder Mystery With Literary Analysis
description: In Cristina Rivera Garza’s novel “Death Takes Me,” a professor becomes both witness and suspect in a gruesome killing spree.
content: The crime that opens Cristina Rivera Garza’s “Death Takes Me” is one of unusual violence, viscerally described with a poet’s compression: “A collection of impossible angles. A skin, the skin. … Ear. Foot. Sex. An open red thing. A context. A boiling point. Something undone.” In an unnamed city, a man has been murdered and castrated, his body left in an alley. The body is discovered by a professor named Cristina Rivera Garza, who is versed in the distinctions between literal and symbolic castration, and who also reports the crime to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Detective Did Jobs for the Mafia on the Side, Prosecutors Say
description: Hector Rosario, a Nassau County detective, raided a gambling operation that competed with the Bonanno crime family, according to federal charges.
content: More than a decade ago, a Nassau County detective burst into a nondescript shoe repair store on Long Island, flanked by colleagues intent on shutting down a backroom gambling operation controlled by the Genovese crime family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Aurelien Breeden
title: How Can Europe Talk to Trump? Flatter, Then Gently Resist.
description: Emmanuel Macron, the French president, epitomized how the continent’s leaders are trying to navigate President Trump’s increasingly hostile administration.
content: Follow live updates on the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak and Somini Sengupta
title: The World Bank Pivoted to Climate. That Now May Be a Problem.
description: The Trump administration’s deep cuts to clean-energy programs are raising concerns about U.S. commitments to the lender.
content: As the Trump administration imposes deep cuts on foreign aid and renewable energy programs, the World Bank, one of the most important financiers of energy projects in developing countries, is facing doubts over whether its biggest shareholder, the United States, will stay on board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arianne Phillips
title: What You Hear if You Listen to the Costumes in ‘A Complete Unknown’
description: Costumes aren’t just for show. They can help develop the character, set a tone, create a feeling and underscore an emotion.
content: Playing Bob Dylan in “A Complete Unknown,” Timothée Chalamet had 67 costume changes. If you didn’t notice, then as the costume designer on the film, I did my job: A mark of success in costume design is your work’s becoming invisible. Clothes help tell the story. But they should not become the story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charley Locke
title: The Morning Ritual That Helps Me Resist the Algorithm
description: Instead of defaulting to the notifications on my phone, poetry has inspired me to begin the day in a different way.
content: Most mornings, as soon as I wake up, I feel the pull of my phone. On a good morning, I reach for some paper and a pen instead, turning on the lamp and scooting back against the pillows so I can prop the paper against my blanketed knees. I grab an index card on which I’ve already copied out the poem I’m memorizing, and, looking at my own shaky handwriting, prepare to copy it again. I write it out, three or four times, enough so that I know it by heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley, Agnes Chang and Amy Chang Chien
title: Taiwan Detains a Chinese-Crewed Ship After Undersea Cable Severed
description: The Coast Guard said it was investigating how the cable was severed and said it could not rule out the possibility of sabotage.
content: Taiwanese authorities said they had detained a cargo ship crewed by Chinese nationals, which investigators believe may have severed an undersea communications cable near the island on Tuesday. It was the latest in a series of murky incidents that have prompted theories that China and Russia may be turning to cable sabotage as a form of harassment at sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Abortion Pill Maker Enters Legal Fight Over F.D.A. Rules
description: GenBioPro, a leading manufacturer of abortion medication, is preparing to go to battle with the Trump administration.
content: The country’s largest manufacturer of abortion pills is wading into the first major legal battle over abortion of President Trump’s second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Marian Turski, Who Refused to Forget the Holocaust, Dies at 98
description: From influential platforms, Mr. Turski, an Auschwitz survivor from Poland, warned the world of rising antisemitism and the perils of indifference to it.
content: Marian Turski, a Holocaust survivor who returned to his native Poland after World War II to give voice to fellow victims of the Nazis and their collaborators, warning the world in writings and speeches about the dangers of indifference to racial and ethnic injustice, died on Feb. 18 at his home in Warsaw. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Judge Gives Trump Administration Deadline to Release Foreign Aid
description: The ruling marked the second the time a federal judge had pushed the Trump administration to act after finding that it had ignored an earlier order.
content: A federal judge on Tuesday directed the Trump administration to unfreeze foreign aid funding within two days after indications that it was failing to comply with a previous court order to keep money flowing to aid groups around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Their Album Is Wordless. Will Their Protest Against A.I. Resound?
description: Musicians including Kate Bush and Billy Ocean released a “silent record” in outrage at a proposed change to British copyright law.
content: Sometimes, silence speaks louder than song.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: In Huntington Beach, Politics on a Plaque
description: MAGA references on a library plaque have divided the Southern California surf town and thrust it into the national spotlight.
content: They call themselves the “MAGA-nificent 7.” They once posed for a picture inside City Hall wearing red caps with the slogan “Make Huntington Beach Great Again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson, Andrew Duehren, Maya C. Miller and Robert Jimison
title: House Passes G.O.P. Budget Teeing Up Enormous Tax and Spending Cuts
description: The vote cleared the way to enact major elements of President Trump’s domestic agenda and escalated a bitter fight among Republicans over what federal programs to shrink to finance major tax cuts.
content: The House on Tuesday narrowly passed a Republican budget resolution that calls for $4.5 trillion in tax cuts and a $2 trillion reduction in federal spending over a decade, clearing the way for major elements of President Trump’s domestic agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: A Fyre Festival Sequel? What Could Go Wrong?
description: Eight years — and one prison sentence — later, Billy McFarland is back with another attempt at the event.
content: Luxury accommodations at a tropical resort. World-class hospitality. “Boundary-pushing” excursions by day. Beachside musical performances by night. And exorbitant ticket prices to boot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Exterior Night’ Review: Life in Perilous Times
description: The Italian master Marco Bellocchio turns to TV, revisiting the mysteries of the Aldo Moro affair.
content: When the great Italian filmmaker Marco Bellocchio made “Good Morning, Night” in 2003, about the 1978 kidnapping and killing of the politician Aldo Moro by the Red Brigades, he provided a fanciful, heartbreaking coda: an image of Moro walking away from captivity, looking not much worse for wear after 55 days in a small cell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: DoorDash to Pay $16.8 Million to Workers for Pocketing Their Tips
description: The payments, part of a settlement with the New York attorney general’s office over a practice that ended in 2019, will return as much as $14,000 to some workers.
content: In the early days of the food-delivery-app explosion, DoorDash came up with a novel way to process tips customers gave to workers: It effectively kept the money for itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye and Julie Creswell
title: Egg Prices Are Soaring. Bird Flu May Not Be the Only Culprit.
description: The nation’s biggest egg producer has seen rising revenues and profits. Now some Democrats are calling for an investigation into pricing practices in the industry.
content: The calls, texts and emails start coming in before 6 in the morning: restaurants, bakeries and others desperate to find eggs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Grangeville’ Review: Am I My Half Brother’s Keeper?
description: A story as old as Cain and Abel gets filtered through cellphone and video confrontations in Samuel D. Hunter’s bleak two-hander.
content: “I don’t know why we have to do this over the phone,” says Arnold, speaking from Rotterdam to his estranged half brother, Jerry, in Idaho.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: New York’s Message to Federal Workers: Come Work for Us
description: “The federal government might say ‘You’re fired,’ but here in New York, we say ‘You’re hired,’” Gov. Kathy Hochul said in a recruiting video. The state has more than 7,000 unfilled government posts.
content: As the Trump administration cuts thousands of workers and leaves many more in limbo, the governor of New York sees a hiring opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Kashmir Hill, Nina Feldman, Sydney Harper, Shannon M. Lin, Mary Wilson, Brendan Klinkenberg, Michael Benoist, Diane Wong, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto, Elisheba Ittoop, Pat McCusker and Chris Wood
title: She Fell in Love With ChatGPT. Like, Actual Love. With Sex.
description: The story of a woman who is dating an A.I. chatbot, and what it tells us about love and technology.
content: Warning: This episode discusses sexual themes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams
title: Inside the Eccentric Japanese-Inspired Studio of a Beloved Berlin Artist
description: The ceramist Oliver Prestele invited friends over to try dishes for his new restaurant.
content: Despite recent waves of gentrification, Berlin is still a city full of artists. While some (including Wolfgang Tillmans and Katharina Grosse) are world-renowned, it’s another cast of characters who keep the city strange and unpredictable. There’s the avant-garde choreographer Florentina Holzinger, for example, known for staging operas with plentiful fake blood, and the 82-year-old fashion knitwear designer Claudia Skoda, who’s often seen out at nightclubs. Then there’s the artist Oliver Prestele, 52, who can be spotted around town wearing fluffy dog-hair hats and giant wooden clogs. Long obsessed with all aspects of traditional Japanese culture, he is one of the city’s most passionate ceramists, a co-owner of some of its most successful Japanese restaurants and a gatherer of people. At the weekly Sunday dinners he hosts at his atelier, one might meet any number of creative Berliners, from the Vietnamese-born Danish artist Danh Vo to the German Japanese classical violinist and artist Ayumi Paul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: I Tried Using an App to Unlock Cabinets at Drugstores
description: The CVS app is in use at three locations in Manhattan. It’s a mixed bag so far.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about an app that lets customers open locked cabinets in three CVS stores in Manhattan without having to seek assistance from an employee. We’ll also get details on revenue for the first month of congestion pricing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Korsha Wilson
title: 4 Black Women Who Mixed Fine Dining, Fashion and Art in New York
description: The dining rooms created by these restaurateurs weren’t just eye-catching; they were stages for their owners’ personal stories.
content: These four restaurants were synonymous with their owners, all serving their takes on soul or Southern food. Before they arrived, a craving for soul food meant heading uptown to Harlem for takeout containers or sitting down at Sylvia’s, opened by Sylvia Woods in 1962 near the famed Apollo Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: The Iron Curtain Casts a Long Shadow Over Germany’s Election
description: The former East Germany still votes virtually as a separate country — and increasingly for a party that has been linked to neo-Nazis.
content: Three and a half decades after reunification, a line runs through Germany where the Iron Curtain once stood. Instead of barbed wires and dogs, that line now divides Germans by measures like income and unemployment — and increasingly by the willingness to vote for extremist parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: A Theory of Media That Explains 15 Years of Politics
description: Martin Gurri discusses how social media and the internet have fundamentally changed the public’s relationship to institutions and power.
content: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Huge Loss at German Central Bank Adds to Gloomy Outlook
description: The central bank’s president said it was “not possible to rule out” a third year of no economic growth.
content: The president of Germany’s central bank, which on Tuesday reported an annual loss for the first time in more than 40 years, said Germany faced another year of economic stagnation, more gloomy news for a country that is struggling to grow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: New York Public Radio to Lay Off About 7% of Staff
description: The elimination of 21 full-time roles is the latest in a series of reductions at the organization.
content: New York Public Radio said on Tuesday that it would lay off about 7 percent of its staff as it continued to struggle with a financial shortfall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: The Sims
description: Have you ever played this game? What did you like about it, if so?
content: The Sims turns 25 this year, and more than 500 million people have played one of the games in this franchise. Are you one of them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Euan Ward
title: Syria’s New Leader Calls for Unity at ‘National Dialogue’
description: Although the conference was called to chart the country’s future, the Kurdish-led militia that controls much of Syria’s northeast was not invited.
content: Syria’s interim president called on Tuesday for unity and the rebuilding of his fractured nation during a two-day conference meant to chart a path forward after decades of dictatorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Benjamin Mullin
title: Paramount and Trump Seek Mediator for CBS News Lawsuit
description: The move is another indicator that the two sides are exploring ways to resolve the case, over the editing of a “60 Minutes” interview, out of court.
content: Lawyers for Paramount and President Trump have agreed to appoint a mediator in his $20 billion lawsuit against CBS, according to two people with knowledge of the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: To the Point: Short Novels Dominate International Booker Prize Nominees
description: Only one of the 13 titles nominated for the prestigious award for fiction translated into English is more than 300 pages long. But it is the one favored by critics.
content: The majority of the books nominated for this year’s International Booker Prize, the prestigious award for fiction translated into English, are under 200 pages long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: What Survivors of the L.A. Fires Took With Them
description: They lost everything in the flames. Now, the things they grabbed as they fled — a stuffed animal and, of all things, peanut butter from the pantry — have taken on a new meaning.
content: The New York Times asked those who lost their homes in the Palisades and Eaton fires to tell us about what they took — what objects or pets they grabbed as they evacuated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Five Weeknight Dinners My Kids Will Gladly Eat
description: They don’t like everything, but they do like mojo chicken with pineapple, sesame salmon bowls and coconut ginger black beans.
content: Here’s a mostly complete list of what my children, ages 5 and 7, eat for dinner:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle and Eli Tan
title: Apple’s Dictation System Transcribes the Word ‘Racist’ as ‘Trump’
description: The company said it was working to fix the problem after iPhone users began reporting the issue.
content: While using Apple’s automatic dictation feature to send messages on Tuesday, some iPhone users reported seeing a peculiar bug: the word “racist” temporarily appearing as “Trump,” before quickly correcting itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
title: U.K. Announces Increase in Military Spending Ahead of Trump Meeting
description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who is set to meet with President Trump on Thursday, said he would increase British spending on defense to 2.5 percent of G.D.P. by 2027.
content: Britain on Tuesday announced a landmark increase in military spending, seeking to send a powerful signal about burden sharing to President Trump before Prime Minister Keir Starmer meets him at the White House on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Poland’s Museums Veered to the Right. A New One Aims for the Middle.
description: For years, lawmakers tried to turn Polish cultural institutions conservative. Now, the revamped Museum of Modern Art in Warsaw wants to avoid getting drawn into politics.
content: During most of the five years when Warsaw’s striking new Museum of Modern Art was under construction, Poland was governed by the conservative Law and Justice Party, whose lawmakers tried to shift the country’s culture to the right. Officials ousted liberal directors at major institutions and replaced them with conservatives whose shows often promoted traditional values and artistic styles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: herculean
description: This word has appeared in 92 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word herculean has appeared in 92 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 14 in “Can the Only Grocery Store in a Rural Michigan Town Stay Independent?” The article is about how the owners of Honor Family Market are ready to retire, but a buyer would face the tight margins of a small business and competition against the giant chains and discount stores. Keith Schneider writes:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Over 230,000 Sign Petition Calling for Musk’s Canadian Citizenship to Be Revoked
description: The petition accused Elon Musk of attacking Canadian sovereignty. The billionaire adviser to President Trump responded on X, saying “Canada is not a real country.”
content: More than 230,000 Canadians have signed a petition to revoke Elon Musk’s Canadian citizenship and passport over what the petition calls his attempts to engage in practices that go against Canada’s national interest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Trump’s Ukraine Mineral Deal Is Seen as ‘Protection Racket’ Diplomacy
description: The United States wants to be paid in exchange for helping the country fend off an invader.
content: Ukraine is nearing a deal to hand over a portion of its revenues from natural resources to the United States, under heavy pressure from the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: ‘A Thousand Blows’ Is a Knuckle Sandwich of a Series
description: From the creator of “Peaky Blinders” comes another brutal and dingy underworld drama, this one set among the boxers and criminals of 1880s London.
content: “A Thousand Blows,” on Hulu, is a grimy historical drama, an evocative boxing drama and a festive crime drama. Its biggest draw, though, is that its creator is Steven Knight, who also created “Peaky Blinders,” and the shows resemble each other quite a bit in their muddy brutality. “Blows” is less brooding, though.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Renaud Philippe
title: Facing Early-Onset Alzheimer’s, She Fought for the Right to Plan Her Death
description: Sandra Demontigny, 45, pushed Quebec to become one of the few places in the world to allow people to choose a medically assisted death sometimes years in advance.
content: One recent evening, Sandra Demontigny tried to write down when she would die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett, Glenn Thrush, Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
title: Trump Takes Aim at Law Firm Aiding Jack Smith
description: The move, signed by President Trump on Thursday, is a major escalation of his promise to pursue perceived foes.
content: President Trump said on Tuesday that he would strip security clearances from lawyers at a prominent Washington law firm aiding a former special counsel who investigated him and end any federal government work the firm may have, intensifying his bid to punish perceived rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz, Elisabetta Povoledo, Emma Bubola and James Hill
title: As Francis Lingers in Critical Condition, an Anxious Wait Intensifies
description: Eleven days after the pope was hospitalized, speculation is mounting and prayers for his recovery verge on a vigil.
content: Vatican City is an anxious place. Clergy keep their phones by their pillows. Reporters, crammed in the Holy See press office, open emails with trepidation. Faithful have begun to gather expectantly in St. Peter’s Square.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Trump’s New Deputy F.B.I. Director Has It Out for the ‘Commie Libs’
description: Dan Bongino is in a place to turn wild notions from the right-wing internet into pretexts for federal investigations.
content: When a New York jury found Donald Trump guilty on 34 felony counts last year, the conservative podcaster Dan Bongino made a veiled threat on social media. “The irony about this for the scumbag commie libs, is that the cold civil war they’re pushing for will end really badly for them,” he wrote. Liberals, said Bongino, had been playing at revolution, and would now get a taste of the real thing. “They’re not ready for what comes next.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Shawn McCreesh
title: Trump Announces Inquiry That Could Lead to Tariffs on Copper
description: Tariffs, if they are imposed, could boost U.S. production of a valuable resource but also raise costs for automakers, construction companies and others.
content: President Trump signed an executive order Tuesday directing his commerce secretary, Howard Lutnick, to begin an investigation into whether foreign production of copper and imports of the material into the United States pose risks to America’s economic and national security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: NASA Gives ‘All Clear’ for Asteroid That Seemed to Threaten Earth
description: The odds that the space rock, 2024 YR4, will smash into our planet in 2032 have dropped to nearly zero, leading astronomers to conclude that we are no longer in danger.
content: Astronomers have been carefully watching 2024 YR4, a space rock with a heightened chance of hitting Earth in 2032. But fear not: NASA announced on Monday that it posed a threat no longer — the odds that the asteroid would smash into our planet have dropped to nearly zero.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: A Second ‘Central Park Five’ Member Will Run for Office in New York
description: Raymond Santana was wrongly imprisoned. Now, he wants to join Yusef Salaam, also wrongfully accused in the rape of a Central Park jogger, on the City Council.
content: Raymond Santana was only 14 in 1989 when he and four other Black and Latino teenagers were wrongfully blamed for the rape of a white female jogger. The case of the so-called Central Park Five transfixed New York City, and their conviction later came to be seen as a notorious injustice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Carville
title: James Carville: It’s Time for a Daring Political Maneuver, Democrats
description: There’s nothing Democrats can legitimately do to stop Trump, so we need a tactical pause in our fight to plan for the future.
content: The Republican Party is all too often effective at campaigning and winning elections, but there’s another fact about it that a lot of Americans forget: The Republican Party flat out sucks at governing. Even Tucker Carlson agrees with this. For all the huffing and puffing on the campaign trail in 2016, the first Trump administration largely amounted to tax cuts for the wealthy, 500 miles of a border wall and a destructive pandemic gone viral. George W. Bush got us into a harebrained war in Iraq and then tried to privatize Social Security while letting our financial system drive smack into the Great Recession. And George H.W. Bush governed his way into a one-term presidency because of the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett
title: Before Ascending to Top Tier of F.B.I., Bongino Fueled Right-Wing Disbelief
description: The post of deputy director will give Dan Bongino access to vast amounts of highly sensitive intelligence, as well as rumor, speculation and false accusations that F.B.I. agents regularly receive.
content: On a recent episode of his wildly popular podcast, the right-wing provocateur Dan Bongino asserted that he would soon be able to show that pipe bombs found near the Capitol the day of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack were “an inside job” and that “the F.B.I. knows who this person is.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: White House Moves to Pick the Pool Reporters Who Cover Trump
description: In announcing plans to hand-select the reporters who can ask the president questions at many events, the White House is breaking decades of precedent.
content: The Trump administration said on Tuesday that it would start handpicking which media outlets were allowed to participate in the presidential press pool, the small, rotating group of reporters who relay the president’s day-to-day activities to the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: ‘Heavyweight,’ an Acclaimed Narrative Podcast, Returns
description: Pushkin Industries, the podcast company that will release the show, is betting that documentary-style audio programs can still win an audience.
content: Almost nine years ago, a Minneapolis writer revealed a family skeleton to a podcast host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 626
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Feb. 26, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: From Jihadist to President: The Evolution of Syria’s New Leader
description: Ahmed al-Shara’s unlikely path from membership in Al Qaeda to head of state has raised questions about how he intends to govern Syria.
content: As the commander of a rebel group allied with Al Qaeda during Syria’s long civil war, the man known by his nom de guerre, Abu Mohammed al-Jolani, welcomed foreign jihadists, dispatched suicide bombers to blow up military posts and vowed to create an Islamic state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: President Trump’s Cuts to Medical Research
description: How government cuts are slowing research.
content: The Trump administration stormed into office, loudly firing workers and closing diversity programs. But behind the scenes, it has also brought biomedical research to the brink of crisis by holding up much of the $47 billion the United States spends on the field every year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Trump Returns to a Favorite Issue: Health Care Price Transparency
description: The president signed an executive order in another push to make the prices of medical services more transparent. Efforts to do so in his first term were largely ignored.
content: In a new executive order, President Trump reaffirmed his commitment to one of his favorite health care policies of his first term: his push to make the prices paid for medical services more public and transparent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: Unknown Deadly Illness Strikes Western Congo
description: The outbreak has been traced, tentatively, to three children who ate a bat, the W.H.O. said, and known threats like Ebola and Marburg have been ruled out.
content: An unidentified illness has killed scores of people and infected hundreds in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the World Health Organization has reported, with preliminary investigations tracing the outbreak to three children who in January ate a bat and died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, Glenn Thrush, Benjamin Weiser, Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Justice Dept.’s No. 2 Targets Old Office Where He Rose as a Prosecutor
description: The forceful approach that Emil Bove III has taken toward the Southern District of New York underscores his own fraught relationship with the office that gave him the expertise to do so.
content: Emil Bove III, the acting deputy attorney general, stood stone-faced and alone at the prosecution table inside the federal courthouse in Manhattan last week to do a job his onetime colleagues in the U.S. attorney’s office for the Southern District of New York would not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Lozada
title: Trump Is on the Border Between Common Sense and Nonsense
description: A lot hinges on how the president invokes the term, which has a rich political history.
content: It will be “a revolution of common sense.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
title: Taiwan Watches Trump Undercut Ukraine, Hoping It Won’t Be Next
description: As President Trump turns toward Russia, Taiwan grapples with its reliance on U.S. support in the face of conflict with China.
content: Soon after Russia invaded Ukraine, Taiwan’s leaders joined the United States and its allies in declaring solidarity with the victim. Taiwan and Ukraine were fellow democracies, they said, each imperiled by its hulking, authoritarian neighbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooke Harrington
title: Trump Is Like F.D.R. — Only in Reverse
description: Undermining one of our country’s greatest and least-appreciated assets.
content: Remember last month, when you didn’t have to think twice about the safety of America’s nuclear arsenal? Or how about last year, when you could file your taxes without wondering if the I.R.S. might share your Social Security number and banking details with an unvetted contractor? Those were the days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Edmund Lee
title: Trump Refocuses on Trade
description: The president has sent the message that he’s committed to tariffs, and that he sees room for deals with Ukraine and Russia.
content: Investors finally seem to be getting the message: Don’t underestimate President Trump’s tariffs threat. The S&P 500 fell on Monday to its lowest level since his inauguration on jitters that a new round of the Trump trade war would kick in next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Two Planes, in Washington and Chicago, Abort Landings to Avoid Collisions
description: The near misses on Tuesday came after a string of aviation disasters, including the midair collision between an Army helicopter and a passenger jet last month that killed 67 people.
content: Within the span of 90 minutes on Tuesday morning, two airplanes, at Washington’s Ronald Reagan National Airport and at Chicago’s Midway International Airport, were forced to abort landings to avoid collisions, federal aviation officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Saying ‘No’ to Musk
description: Some cabinet officials are showing a glimmer of willingness to check the billionaire’s power.
content: They have laid off their own workers. They have reshuffled their departments’ priorities. They have taken aim at D.E.I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Woman Will Plead Guilty in Scheme to Defraud Presleys and Sell Graceland
description: Prosecutors had accused the woman of creating fraudulent loan documents and forging Lisa Marie Presley’s signature.
content: A Missouri woman agreed to plead guilty to mail fraud on Tuesday for her role in orchestrating what the authorities described as a scheme to defraud Elvis Presley’s heirs by claiming ownership of Graceland, his Memphis home, and threatening to sell it in a foreclosure auction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Al Trautwig, 68, Mainstay in the TV Booth at Madison Square Garden, Dies
description: The Long Island native covered 16 Olympics, and had cameos in the movie “Cool Runnings” and the TV show “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.”
content: Al Trautwig, who brought sports fans along with him to New York’s Canyon of Heroes, champagne-doused locker rooms and the medal podium at the Olympics over a broadcast career that spanned more than three decades, died on Sunday at his home on Long Island. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: How Far Do Trump’s Cuts to Science Reach? To the Ends of the Earth.
description: The National Science Foundation has fired workers at the office that manages polar research, raising fears about a reduced U.S. presence in two strategic regions.
content: Kelly Brunt wasn’t the only federal employee to be laid off this month while traveling for work. But she was almost certainly the only one whose work trip was in Antarctica.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Córdova
title: At This Architectural Gem, an Artist Was Present. Horses, Too.
description: The performance artist Marina Abramovic celebrated the announcement of a new cultural center in a private home designed by the famed Mexican architect Luis Barragán.
content: One of the most anticipated events of an overstuffed Mexico City Art Week earlier this month promised to be a surreal collision of architecture, performance art, power, privilege — and horses. Marina Abramovic, the grandmother of performance art, would be presenting her latest works (though she would dispute recognizing them as such) at a house and horse stable designed by Luis Barragán, Mexico’s famed midcentury architect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: A Gucci Bag That Puts Its Signature Front and Center
description: The brand’s latest iteration of a ’70s accessory makes the horse bit the main event.
content: As a teenager in the late 1890s, Guccio Gucci traveled from Florence to London, where he soon began to work as a porter at the Savoy hotel. Inspired by the memory of the establishment’s stylish international guests, in 1921 he opened a leather goods and luggage atelier on Florence’s Via della Vigna Nuova. Gucci found success by combining Tuscan craftsmanship with English elegance; by midcentury, the house had also become known for its equestrian motifs: Handbags in the shape of saddles were introduced in the late 1940s, and Guccio’s son Aldo incorporated horse bit hardware for his debut loafer collection in 1953. Within a decade or so, the horse bit emblem adorned belts, jewelry, watches, silks and ready-to-wear. In 1973, the brand released its now-iconic bucket bag, featuring a horse bit clasp inspired by a bridle at the center of its suede-and-leather silhouette, with a buckle on the shoulder strap in the shape of a stirrup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Neal E. Boudette
title: Tesla Shares Fall 8% as Post-Election Surge Dissipates
description: The electric-car maker’s stock has had a bumpy ride since the victory of President Trump, who has given Tesla’s chief, Elon Musk, a role in Washington.
content: Shares of Tesla had been on a tear since Donald J. Trump won the presidential election. Investors were betting that the carmaker would benefit from the more than $250 million that its chief executive, Elon Musk, spent to support the Trump campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Oreskes
title: After Public Clash Over Tolls, Hochul Tries to Persuade Trump Privately
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York said that she and President Trump discussed congestion pricing, which Mr. Trump has moved to kill, in an unscheduled meeting on Friday.
content: Last week, after Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York had theatrically laid down a “Rambo”-inspired challenge to President Trump, she found herself in Washington, face to face with the president’s deputy chief of staff, Stephen Miller.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Golden Era Begins for a Korean Restaurant Near Rockefeller Center
description: Golden Diner’s owner has taken over his family’s business at Golden HOF/NY Kimchi, and more restaurant news.
content: The restaurateur Sam Yoo’s latest is a legacy. An owner of Golden Diner in Chinatown, Mr. Yoo has taken over his family’s duplex restaurant near Rockefeller Center, previously New York Kimchi serving Korean barbecue. The setup now has a Korean pub, called a hof, on the upper floor with drinks and anju (bar food) like fried chicken, chive pancakes, carbonara rice cakes, dumplings and a cheeseburger. The lower level is NY Kimchi, with a more elaborate steakhouse menu (steaks and fish served with banchan) as well as raw bar specialties, including oysters Rockefeller with kimchi butter, along with Korean dishes, including japchae noodles, salads and jeon pancakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Once the Center of the N.B.A. News Universe, These Phones Can Now Be Yours
description: Adrian Wojnarowski, the former king of the N.B.A. scoop at ESPN, is auctioning off personal items to raise money for his employer, St. Bonaventure University.
content: Sports journalists can collect a lot of detritus: old ID cards, press credentials to get into big games, phones that stop working or become obsolete. Most of it winds up in the trash, unvalued and worthless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Would You Pay $34 for Shrimp Cocktail?
description: A lot of people do.
content: The shrimp cocktail at the comically exclusive Polo Bar in Manhattan is an imposing specimen, the crustaceans arriving tightly shingled on a steeple of ice accented by a celery spire. To devour one in a single bite would be gluttonous. Each requires at least three bites to enjoy — and to ensure the tail meat is excavated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Tesla Moves One Step Closer to Self-Driving Cars in China
description: The development marked a breakthrough for Tesla’s chief executive, Elon Musk, in a country where his company has faced increasingly tough competition.
content: Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, tried for years to persuade Chinese regulators to let him offer self-driving capabilities in one of the company’s most important markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: In the Trump Era, Crafting a State Budget Becomes More Complicated
description: With funding from Washington uncertain, New Jersey, like other states, is budgeting cautiously.
content: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey proposed a $58 billion budget on Tuesday that would keep spending roughly flat as the state braces for potentially drastic reductions in federal funding, including Medicaid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas, Kate Conger and Ryan Mac
title: A mystery solved: Amy Gleason, former health care executive, is running DOGE.
description: Ms. Gleason is the acting administrator of the Department of Government Efficiency, according to a White House official. The news comes as a federal judge questioned who was leading the operation.
content: Amy Gleason, a former health care investment executive, is serving as the acting administrator of the Department of Government Efficiency, the government-overhaul task force imposing dramatic changes across the federal bureaucracy under the direction of Elon Musk, a White House official said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What 15 Americans Think About Elon Musk’s Role in U.S. Government
description: Americans across the country are deeply split over Mr. Musk, with some welcoming his cuts to government and others outraged at what they see as an abuse of power.
content: With surprising speed and the support of President Trump, the billionaire Elon Musk and the employees of his newly created cost-cutting outfit have laid off thousands of federal workers, gutted the U.S. Agency for International Development, and put on hold dozens of health research efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Andrew Cuomo Is Said to Be Nearing a Run for Mayor
description: The former governor, who resigned in disgrace, has not officially entered the New York City mayoral race. But he has spent months laying the groundwork.
content: Three years after resigning the governorship in a cloud of scandal, Andrew M. Cuomo is making final preparations to run for mayor of New York City and could announce his candidacy as soon as this weekend, according to four people familiar with the planning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Conductor at the Top, and Still Learning on the Job
description: Antonio Pappano, who leads the London Symphony Orchestra, feels like he is always “playing catch-up” because he skipped music school.
content: It was just a few hours before a concert, and the London Symphony Orchestra was only now rehearsing with its star soloist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: 7 New Songs You Should Hear Now
description: Hear new music from Doechii, Valerie June, Perfume Genius and others.
content: Did any musician have a better February than Doechii?* Going into this month, the Tampa, Fla., rapper and self-proclaimed Swamp Princess was a rising star but hardly a household name. Then on Feb. 2, she had a breakout night at the Grammys, giving an unforgettable (and impressively gymnastic) performance that showcased the full scope of her artistic vision, pulling off an upset win in the best rap album category for her razor-sharp “Alligator Bites Never Heal” and giving one of the night’s most memorable, emotional speeches. If you didn’t know her in January, you know her now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: A Ballerina Steps Into the Spotlight With Swan Queen Confidence
description: Miriam Miller, newly promoted to principal at New York City Ballet, is set to make her debut in “Swan Lake.”
content: Elegance has a way of pouring out of Miriam Miller. Her arms open like wings, her fingertips part like petals. At 5 foot 10, with long legs and an elastic back, she has the kind of line that goes on for days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Yan
title: Government Workers Who Have Lost Their Jobs Worry About Their Housing
description: The abrupt firings have left federal workers and contractors throughout the country in flux, with many distressed over how they will pay the mortgage or rent.
content: After losing his job at the U.S. Forest Service, Cameron McKenzie was worried about finding a new job. But first, he had a more immediate concern: How was he going to pay the mortgage?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Under Trump, America’s New Friends: Russia, North Korea and Belarus
description: When it comes to the war in Ukraine, President Trump finds common cause with the world’s outlier states and stands against traditional U.S. allies like Britain, France, Germany, Canada, Japan and Italy.
content: If the old saying is true, that you are known by who your friends are, then President Trump may be telling the world something about who he plans to be in this second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane L. Levere
title: For $18.75 Million, You Can Live Lavishly in the Waldorf Astoria
description: The building’s Art Deco charm has been adapted for the 372 residences and over 50,000 square feet of new amenities.
content: The Waldorf Astoria New York, which has been closed since 2017, is selling new residences, with some already occupied before the revamped hotel reopens this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren
title: Acting I.R.S. Commissioner Is Expected to Announce His Retirement
description: Doug O’Donnell, a 40-year veteran of the I.R.S., was elevated last month after the last commissioner stepped down at the beginning of President Trump’s term.
content: The acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service is expected to announce on Tuesday that he is retiring, according to three people familiar with the move, the latest agency head to depart after Elon Musk’s team pushed for access to sensitive data and mass layoffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Brown
title: Trump’s Transportation Dept. Targets Blue State Priorities
description: The Trump administration has set its sights on high speed rail in California and congestion pricing in New York, worrying transportation experts.
content: The Department of Transportation delivered a blow to big transportation projects in the two most populous blue states last week when it moved to revoke its approval of New York City’s congestion pricing program and announced a review of California’s high speed rail project the next day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: At France’s Oldest Theater, Things Change, but They Also Stay the Same
description: A new leader for the Comédie-Française, Clément Hervieu-Léger, is an insider who looks set to keep the venerable Paris company on a steady course.
content: Later this year, the actor and director Clément Hervieu-Léger will assume one of the most influential positions in French theater: general administrator of the Comédie-Française, the country’s oldest active company. France’s culture ministry announced the appointment last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: An Author Who Builds Outfits Around Hats
description: She also takes style cues from clowns.
content: On Valentine’s Day, the streets of Manhattan were a charming sight: So many people were wearing reds and pinks that conjured the spirit of a day known for romantic dates and fancy dinners. But few that I saw looked more eclectic than Fée Brandt, a 24-year-old author and illustrator of children’s books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: How a Demographic ‘Doom Loop’ Helped Germany’s Far Right
description: Understanding the Alternative for Germany’s success in Sunday’s elections.
content: The Alternative for Germany party came in second in federal elections on Sunday, doubling its vote share from four years ago, in the strongest showing for a German far-right party since World War II. Some segments of the party, known as the AfD, have been classified as extremist by German intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Totally Beat
description: Greg Snitkin’s puzzle takes us back in time.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colby Smith and Ben Casselman
title: Americans Are Expecting Higher Prices. That Could Unnerve the Fed.
description: More Americans are starting to brace for higher prices as President Trump’s policies begin to take effect.
content: Fresh off the worst inflation shock in decades, Americans are once again bracing for higher prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana H. Allin and Jonathan Stevenson
title: America and Russia Are on the Same Side Now
description: The U.S. is embracing European far-right parties in sympathy with Moscow — the opposite of how Washington dealt with Europe’s Communist parties in the Cold War.
content: During the Cold War, large and influential Communist parties in Western Europe maintained ties with Moscow, ranging from sympathetic to subservient. The United States kept its distance and in many cases supported their opponents financially and politically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Greenblatt
title: She Remembers Everything. Except What Happened to Her Yesterday.
description: In Karen Thompson Walker’s latest novel, “The Strange Case of Jane O.,” a patient’s unusual symptoms suggest metaphysical mysteries.
content: The man who mistook his wife for a hat; the girl so woefully abused that she developed more than a dozen distinct personalities: Psychiatry’s famous case studies can sound as fantastical as fiction. (And they sometimes were, in fact, too outrageous to be true.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo and Michael D. Shear
title: As Trump Eyes the Postal Service, Concerns Grow Over Its Independence
description: White House officials say they have no immediate plans to take over the service. But the president suggested he would consider a major reorganization of the agency.
content: President Trump’s attempt to exert more control over the U.S. Postal Service has fueled concerns that those efforts could hurt the agency’s ability to reliably deliver mail to all corners of the country, a mandate that is core to its mission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,348
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Feb. 26, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 25, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025.
content: An article on Saturday about what Black Americans think about President Trump’s actions in his first month in office omitted political affiliations for Javon Evans and Paul James Jr. Mr. Evans volunteers as communications director for the Houston Young Republicans and Mr. James serves as the president of the Young Republicans of Bexar County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Grants New Trial to Death Row Inmate in Oklahoma
description: Both sides had told the justices that long-suppressed evidence had undermined the case against the inmate, Richard Glossip.
content: The Supreme Court on Tuesday granted a new trial to Richard Glossip, a death row inmate in Oklahoma whose challenge to his conviction led to an extraordinary concession from the state’s attorney general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: 21 DOGE Staff Members Quit, Refusing to Assist Musk’s Effort
description: The employees had worked for the U.S. Digital Service, a technology-focused unit rebranded by Mr. Musk and empowered by President Trump.
content: A group of 21 civil servants with technology expertise resigned on Tuesday rather than help implement an array of changes to the federal government being pushed by the billionaire Elon Musk and his Department of Government Efficiency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattathias Schwartz
title: Judge Blocks Trump Executive Order to Suspend Refugee Program
description: The preliminary injunction orders the government to effectively restore the decades-old U.S. Refugee Admissions Program while a lawsuit to preserve it proceeds.
content: A federal judge in Seattle on Tuesday blocked an executive order that President Trump signed shortly after he was sworn in that suspended a decades-old program admitting thousands of refugees into the United States each year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Goodman
title: 1,200 Acres of Powder for Around $100: Skiing a Vermont Gem
description: Brought back from the brink by devoted skiers and a new generation of a skiing family, Bolton Valley has cultivated a niche among Eastern ski areas as an affordable downhill and backcountry resort.
content: Bolton Valley Resort, about 30 minutes east of Burlington, Vt., has long been overshadowed by larger, more famous neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: Reflecting on 20 Years of Canada Reporting
description: In a Times newsletter, a journalist based in Ottawa covers the people and events shaping his country.
content: A plane crash at Toronto Pearson International Airport. A scandal at Hockey Canada. Sasquatch sightings in British Columbia. And, now, a newly elected American president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: America’s Most Shameful Vote Ever at the U.N.
description: What happens when we stop “living within the truth.”
content: In the spring of 2007, I interviewed Václav Havel on a bench in the garden of Prague’s Czernin Palace. The playwright and former Czech president discussed his shifting views on the war in Iraq, the role of art in unfree states, the dangers of political obsession and indifference — and his yearning, 11 years after he had quit smoking, for a cigarette.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Government Watchdog Moves to Protect Probationary Federal Workers
description: Hampton Dellinger, the head of the Office of Special Counsel, recommended pausing the mass firings of some probationary federal employees.
content: A government watchdog lawyer whose dismissal by President Trump has been stalled by the courts announced on Monday that his office would seek to pause the mass firings of some probationary federal workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Why ‘Probationary’ Employees Are a Target in Federal Job Cuts
description: Many government workers being cut are those with fewer protections. They are relatively new in their current jobs, but often have years of experience.
content: In news about the Trump administration’s job-slashing effort, one class of federal workers comes up repeatedly: “probationary” employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold, Aatish Bhatia, Margot Sanger-Katz, Emily Badger, Ethan Singer and Josh Katz
title: DOGE Quietly Deletes the 5 Biggest Spending Cuts It Celebrated Last Week
description: The cuts, highlighted on an earlier version of the “wall of receipts” posted by Elon Musk’s team, contained mistakes that vastly inflated the amount of money saved.
content: Last week, Elon Musk’s government cost-slashing initiative, which he calls the Department of Government Efficiency, posted an online “wall of receipts,” celebrating how much it had saved by canceling federal contracts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: She Interrupted a Town-Hall Meeting and Was Dragged Out by Private Security
description: The City of Coeur d’Alene revoked the license of a security firm after its plainclothes guards forcibly removed a woman. The police said they were investigating the incident.
content: The woman had been heckling speakers and speaking out at a town-hall meeting hosted by local Republicans in Coeur d’Alene, a small city in northern Idaho. The local sheriff asked her to leave, even pulling at her arm at one point and threatening to arrest her, according to videos from the event that have been published online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: In Hate Crime Trial, Mother of Slain Palestinian American Boy Testifies
description: Prosectors argued that the 2023 killing of Wadee Alfayoumi, 6, in suburban Chicago was motivated by anti-Muslim hate.
content: Hanan Shaheen walked to the front of an Illinois courtroom on Tuesday and described how, in a matter of days her landlord turned on her and her 6-year-old son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Hegseth Returns to Guantánamo, This Time as Defense Secretary
description: Mr. Hegseth served at the U.S. Navy base as a National Guard lieutenant. The base is now being used to hold some migrants who face deportation.
content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth visited the U.S. Navy base at Guantánamo Bay in Cuba on Tuesday to observe the Trump administration’s migrant detention operations there, and get a briefing on the base’s prison housing detainees in the war against terrorism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young and Yan Zhuang
title: 4 Workers Killed in Highway Bridge Collapse in South Korea
description: Six others were injured when part of a highway construction site broke apart on Tuesday morning, officials said.
content: Four workers were killed, and six others were injured when part of a highway bridge under construction collapsed in South Korea on Tuesday morning, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Facing Trump’s Hostility, Ukraine Weighs Its Options. But They Are Few.
description: There is a broad reckoning in Ukraine: Washington can no longer be relied upon as a supporter. But Kyiv still has agency on the battlefield and can seek increased support from Europe.
content: The antagonistic messaging President Trump has delivered to Ukraine since taking office has presented leaders in Kyiv with a brutal reckoning: that the United States can no longer be counted on as a supporter, and may even be an adversary, in the effort to end the war with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Sarah Kliff
title: As G.O.P. Eyes Medicaid Cuts, States Could be Left With Vast Shortfalls
description: Republicans have proposed lowering the federal share of costs for Medicaid expansions, which could reshape the program by gutting one of the Affordable Care Act’s major provisions.
content: House Republicans hunting for ways to pay for President Trump’s tax cuts have called for cutting the federal government’s share of Medicaid spending, including a proposal that would effectively gut the Affordable Care Act’s 2014 expansion of the program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Bill Burr Is About to Hit Broadway. Broadway Better Duck.
description: The acerbic comic sounds like a Mamet character, and thanks to Nathan Lane, he’s making his Broadway debut as one in “Glengarry Glen Ross.”
content: Inside a spacious room on Manhattan’s West Side, rehearsal for the latest Broadway revival of David Mamet’s “Glengarry Glen Ross” was full of macho bluster and trash talk. And that was before the actors started running their scene.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Three Years: Reflections on the Ukraine War
description: Readers reflect on the anniversary. Also: Advice for Democrats; lab discoveries lost; pennies and nickels; re-evaluating movies.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Trump Plans ‘Gold Card’ Alternative to Green Cards for ‘High Level People’
description: President Trump said the cards would have “a higher level of sophistication” than green cards and cost applicants about $5 million.
content: President Trump on Tuesday previewed his plans for a new visa program he was calling the gold card, describing it as “somewhat like a green card, but at a higher level of sophistication.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Some Republicans Sharply Criticize Trump’s Embrace of Russia at the U.N.
description: Their pointed remarks followed votes on Monday in which the United States broke with allies to side with Russia over the war in Ukraine.
content: A band of traditional Republicans in Congress sharply criticized the Trump administration this week for siding with Russia at the United Nations on resolutions regarding the war in Ukraine, even as the majority of the G.O.P. turned a blind eye to the United States’ sudden embrace of a longtime adversary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
title: At Stake in Ukraine-Trump Deal: Titanium, Lithium and Rare Earths
description: The country has a bounty of minerals and other natural resources, including gas and oil, but they may not be easy to extract.
content: Officials in Ukraine and the Trump administration say they are close to a deal that would give the United States revenues from Ukraine’s minerals and other natural resources, including titanium, lithium, oil, natural gas and rare earth elements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: The Chaos Agenda Is Going Full Speed Ahead
description: The president and his allies are using their drive to slash the size of the federal work force to break the bonds of restraint.
content: President Trump is sowing chaos at a blistering pace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut, Andrew E. Kramer and Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. and Ukraine Agree to Minerals Deal, Officials Say
description: President Trump, who had insisted he wanted “payback” for past military aid to Kyiv, suggested President Volodymyr Zelensky would visit Washington this week to sign an agreement, which he called a “very big deal.”
content: Ukraine has agreed to turn over the revenue from some of its mineral resources to the United States, an American and a Ukrainian official said on Tuesday, in a deal that follows an intense pressure campaign from President Trump that included insults and threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Tension between Europe and the U.S. over Ukraine.
content: President Trump met with his French counterpart, Emmanuel Macron, at the White House yesterday, three years to the day after Russia began its full-scale invasion of Ukraine. The leaders diverged significantly over the war’s causes, each side’s role in the conflict and its possible resolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Laughs at DOGE’s Work Force Demand
description: “It’s like the government is being run by BuzzFeed,” Jimmy Kimmel said on Monday about Elon Musk’s work-tracking request to federal employees.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon and Ellen Yan
title: Coast Guard Suspends Rescue Efforts After Boat Capsizes Near Queens
description: Six passengers had been aboard the small boat that overturned in the Ambrose Channel on Sunday. At least three of them died, officials said, and one man could not be found.
content: Cecilio Adames met up with five friends Sunday morning at a dock in Howard Beach, Queens. The group planned to go fishing on a boat one of them owned.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: A Majestic Chart-Topper Who Thrilled Us Softly
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 25, 2025.
content: “The thing that engulfs me in music is the pulse. If I can find that heartbeat, I can live in there — in that music.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What We Know About the U.S.-Ukraine Minerals Deal
description: A draft agreement discussed on Tuesday does not include a $500 billion payout the Trump administration demanded earlier.
content: Ukraine has agreed to a deal to turn over the revenue from some of its mineral resources to the United States, an American and a Ukrainian official said on Tuesday, after an intense pressure campaign from President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Will Jarvis, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and Constant Méheut
title: A Showdown on Ukraine, and a Judge Says DOGE Might Be Unconstitutional
description: Plus, Roberta Flack remembered.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: 2 Men Held in New York City Jails Die in a Week, Officials Say
description: The deaths were the first in 2025 to be connected to the Rikers Island jail complex, which may be taken over by a court-appointed receiver.
content: A 55-year-old man awaiting trial on murder and other charges died in a holding area at a Manhattan courthouse on Monday, according to officials and court records. He was the second person to die in Correction Department custody in the past week, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: State Election Officials Seek to Avert Deeper Cuts
description: The National Association of Secretaries of State, normally reluctant to wade into partisan politics, has asked the homeland security secretary to preserve election security programs.
content: Alarmed by cuts already made to federal agencies that help safeguard elections, and fearful that more could be coming, a bipartisan group of the nation’s top state election officials has appealed to Kristi Noem, the secretary of homeland security, for help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Jeremy Engle
title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Russia-Ukraine War, Quantum Computing, S.N.L.
description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Leventhal
title: Trump Administration Announces It Will Now Choose Pool Reporters
description: The White House press secretary, Karoline Leavitt, announced on Tuesday that the Trump administration will now choose which media outlets can access the presidential pool.
content: The White House press secretary, Karoline Leavitt, announced on Tuesday that the Trump administration will now choose which media outlets can access the presidential pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press, Reuters and Chang W. Lee
title: 4 Killed and 6 Injured in Highway Bridge Collapse in South Korea
description: Part of a highway bridge under construction collapsed near the city of Cheonan, about 50 miles south of Seoul, South Korea’s capital.
content: Part of a highway bridge under construction collapsed near the city of Cheonan, about 50 miles south of Seoul, South Korea’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Bridge Collapse Kills Several in South Korea
description: Emergency crews searched for survivors and worked to clear rubble from the site, which was part of a highway construction project in Cheonan, South Korea.
content: Emergency crews searched for survivors and worked to clear rubble from the site, which was part of a highway construction project in Cheonan, South Korea.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Theory of Media That Explains 15 Years of Politics
description: Martin Gurri discusses how social media and the internet have fundamentally changed the public’s relationship to institutions and power.
content: Martin Gurri discusses how social media and the internet have fundamentally changed the public’s relationship to institutions and power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nader Ibrahim
title: Forcible Removal of Idaho Townhall Heckler Prompts Investigation
description: Teresa Borrenpohl was grabbed and detained by plainclothes men from a private security firm after disrupting a legislative town hall meeting in Coeur d’Alene, Idaho. The chaos has prompted a police investigation.
content: Teresa Borrenpohl was grabbed and detained by plainclothes men from a private security firm after disrupting a legislative town hall meeting in Coeur d’Alene, Idaho. The chaos has prompted a police investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ang Li
title: Catholics Pray for Pope Francis as He Battles Pneumonia
description: On Tuesday night, the Vatican said the pope was in “critical but stable” condition.
content: On Tuesday night, the Vatican said the pope was in “critical but stable” condition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Paik
title: Trump and Macron Showcase Friendship, and Some Differences
description: President Trump and President Emmanuel Macron of France traded compliments during a meeting at the White House. But they struck different tones on the war in Ukraine.
content: President Trump and President Emmanuel Macron of France traded compliments during a meeting at the White House. But they struck different tones on the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times
